notes.title: Mughal Architecture — Signature Features & Case Studies
notes.content:
Key traits: double dome, charbagh planning, iwans, pietra dura, onion domes, red sandstone + white marble, symmetry/axiality.
Case studies to quote: Taj Mahal, Buland Darwaza (Fatehpur Sikri), Moti Masjid (Agra Fort), Shalimar Gardens (Lahore).
keyTakeaways: Be able to list hallmark features and link each to a monument.
Use UNESCO descriptions for authoritative facts (dates, dimensions).
Contrast Akbar's red sandstone phase vs Shah Jahan's marble aesthetic.

notes.title: Sher Shah Suri's Reforms — Administration, Currency, Roads
notes.content: Core measures: land revenue reforms, standard coinage (Rupiya), sarais & GT Road, efficient intelligence/administration; continuity into Mughal rule.
keyTakeaways: Link Sher Shah's measures to Akbar's consolidation.
Mention coinage standardization and GT Road for MCQs.
Use balanced, source-backed specifics.

resources.title: IGNCA e-book chapter (Jadunath Sarkar, Mughal Administration)

notes.title: Akbar's Rajput Policy & Dīn-i-Ilāhī
notes.content: Rajput accommodation through alliances/offices; synthesis and religious tolerance; Dīn-i-Ilāhī as elite ethical order (limited following).
keyTakeaways: Differentiate broad sulh-i-kul from Dīn-i-Ilāhī.
Explain how Rajput policy stabilized frontiers.
Cite primary compendium (Ain-i-Akbari) for admin details.

notes.title: Mansabdari System — Backbone of Mughal Administration
notes.content: Ranks (mansab), zat/sawar distinctions, jagir assignments, and its role in imperial cohesion and later stresses.
keyTakeaways: Define zat vs sawar and why it matters for pay/contingents.
Link jagirdari pressures to Mughal decline debates.
Use Ain-i-Akbari as anchor reference.

resources.title: Cambridge History (context note on Tarikh-i Firoz Shahi & admin)

notes.title: Decline of the Mughals — Multi-Factor Explanations
notes.content: Court factionalism, jagirdari crisis, military overstretch (Deccan), succession wars, European maritime shift; use Jadunath Sarkar and case-based evidence.
keyTakeaways: Avoid mono-causal answers; present interplay of fiscal/admin/military factors.
Quote Deccan campaigns and revenue strain.
Use late-Mughal source material where possible.

resources.title: Jadunath Sarkar — Fall of the Mughal Empire (Vol. I)

notes.title: Alauddin Khalji's Market & Price Controls
notes.content: Market regulation to keep army maintenance cheap: fixed prices, rationing, checks on hoarding, and strong intelligence.
keyTakeaways: Explain linkage to military policy and revenue needs.
Cite Barani and modern analyses; note debates on feasibility.
Mention punishments/administrative apparatus.

resources.title: Irfan Habib — Price Regulation of Alauddin Khalji (paper)
College handout — Market Policy of Alauddin

notes.title: Muhammad bin Tughluq — Reforms & Reversals
notes.content: Token currency, capital shift to Daulatabad, taxation; ambition vs execution and administrative capacity.
keyTakeaways: Define why token currency failed (counterfeiting, trust).
Balance innovation with governance pitfalls.
Use a standard reference + quick academic reads.

notes.title: Balban's 'Blood & Iron' Consolidation
notes.content: Centralization, spy network, crushing of nobles/robber tribes, curbing the 'Chahalgani'.
keyTakeaways: Connect policy to Mongol threat and internal stability.
Use neutral, fact-rich reference.
Name key institutions and measures.

notes.title: Indo-Islamic Culture — Amir Khusrau & Cultural Synthesis
notes.content: Persianate literary culture, music (qawwali lore), multilingual output; Khusrau as emblem of composite culture.
keyTakeaways: Quote a couple of works/titles to ground answers.
Situate Khusrau within Sultanate court culture.
Use primary/secondary open sources.

resources.title: Archive — The Life and Works of Amir Khusrau (1935)

notes.title: Ain-i-Akbari & Mughal Administration (Source-based Answers)
notes.content: Use Ain-i-Akbari for mansabs, revenue admin, court protocols; cite specific books/sections where possible.
keyTakeaways: Bring 1–2 concrete data points from Ain to score.
Pair with modern commentary where needed.
Keep brief quotes if allowed.

notes.title: Two-Nation Theory — Origins & Debates
notes.content: Intellectual roots (Sir Syed, Muslim modernism), political articulation (Iqbal 1930), and evolving interpretations.
keyTakeaways: Anchor with Iqbal's 1930 presidential address.
Contrast scholarly views; avoid teleology.
Tie to Partition outcomes cautiously.

notes.title: Aligarh Movement — Sir Syed's Educational & Political Vision
notes.content: MAO College, modern education, loyalist politics, communal representation arguments; impact on Muslim elite formation.
keyTakeaways: Connect to Muslim League's later politics.
Use specific institutional milestones.
Add a crisp definition for MCQs.

resources.title: Scholarly paper on Sir Syed & elites

notes.title: Partition of Bengal (1905) — Causes, Protest & Annulment
notes.content: Administrative rationale vs nationalist backlash; Swadeshi movement; annulment (1911).
keyTakeaways: Quote the 1905 announcement and reactions.
Place in broader anti-colonial mobilization.
Useful for short notes + MCQs.

notes.title: Khilafat Movement (1919–24) — Pan-Islam & Indian Nationalism
notes.content: Goals (Caliphate), alliance with Non-Cooperation, abolition of Caliphate and decline; effects on Hindu-Muslim unity.
keyTakeaways: Name key leaders and timeline.
Tie to Gandhi's program and outcomes.
Use concise, authoritative reference.

notes.title: Lucknow Pact (1916) — Congress–League Agreement
notes.content: Separate electorates, weightage, representation shares; brief window of cooperation.
keyTakeaways: List 3–4 clauses verbatim for exam answers.
Explain why it mattered later (breakdown).

notes.title: Cabinet Mission Plan (1946) — Proposals & Outcome
notes.content: Three-tier federation, groupings A/B/C, central subjects limited; acceptance/rejection dynamics and path to Partition.
keyTakeaways: Memorize members & date.
Understand grouping logic for essay diagrams.
Relate to Mountbatten Plan timeline.

resources.title: Cabinet Mission in India (1946) — primary material

notes.title: Objective(s) Resolution (1949) — Constitutional Compass
notes.content: Sovereignty of Allah, democracy/justice/freedom, minorities' rights; later as preamble and substantive provisions.
keyTakeaways: Date: 12 March 1949; mover: Liaquat Ali Khan.
Know its later incorporation in constitutional texts.

notes.title: Constitutions of Pakistan — 1956 & 1973 (Core Features)
notes.content: 1956: first constitution, Islamic Republic, parliamentary; 1973: enduring framework with later amendments; center–province dynamics, fundamental rights.
keyTakeaways: Quote 2–3 salient features for each.
Know amendment landscape at a high level.
Use official PDFs for citations.

notes.title: Indus Waters Treaty (1960) — Text & Exam Angles
notes.content: River allocation (Indus system), World Bank's role, dispute mechanisms; recurring in MCQs and essays (water security).
keyTakeaways: Memorize date: 19 Sept 1960; parties & broker.
Know basic allocations (Western vs Eastern rivers).
Cite official treaty PDF.

resources.title: UN Treaty Series — Indus Waters Treaty (official)

notes.title: Simla Agreement (1972) — Post-War Framework
notes.content: Bilateralism principle, LoC recognition, normalization steps; shows up in MCQs/short notes.
keyTakeaways: Date: 2 July 1972; know key clauses.
Understand why parties return to Simla in disputes.

notes.title: 1971: Separation of East Pakistan — Reports & Documents
notes.content: Causes and course of the conflict; use commission report + contemporaneous documentation for balanced answers.
keyTakeaways: Reference Hamoodur Rahman Commission for inquiry findings.
Consult ICJ 1972 report for international law perspective.
Mention GOP White Paper (Aug 1971) as primary viewpoint.

resources.title: International Commission of Jurists — Events in East Pakistan (1972)

notes.title: Kashmir — UN Resolutions & Diplomatic Texts
notes.content: Essential to know early UNSC resolutions (e.g., Resolution 47, 1948) and ceasefire/plebiscite language.
keyTakeaways: Quote Resolution 47's plebiscite principle.
Keep links to primary UN docs handy for answers.

notes.title: Delhi Sultanate — Political Theory & Sources
notes.content: Barani's perspective on polity, social hierarchy; pair with Afif's Tarikh-i-Firoz Shahi and Elliot-Dowson translations.
keyTakeaways: Understand authorial bias in Sultanate chronicles.
Use translations to quote administrative practices.

resources.title: Barani — Tarikh-i Firoz Shahi (translation, Afif version)
The Political Theory of the Delhi Sultanate (study)

notes.title: Primary Text — Bābur-Nāma (for Early Mughal Context)
notes.content: Use Beveridge translation for geography, warfare, and early Mughal statecraft; great for vivid quotes.
keyTakeaways: Cite book & chapter for credibility.
Use sparingly to illustrate state formation.

notes.title: Pakistan & the OIC — Roles & Statements
notes.content: Pakistan's activism within OIC platforms; useful for short, contemporary IR notes.
keyTakeaways: Know OIC's structure and Pakistan's engagements.
Use official communiqués for quotes.

notes.title: Exam-Focused Videos — Medieval & Partition
notes.content: Use curated UPSC-centric lectures for rapid revision; pair with primary/authoritative sources above.
keyTakeaways: Watch for frameworks/diagrams (groupings, admin charts).
Cross-verify facts from videos with texts.

resources.title: BBC — Partition: The Day India Burned (2007)
